recordings.rmk: A breeding colony of Rook is set on a small copse of poplar trees.
A Rook colony on some big trees near a road. Check my website www.birdsongs.it
Loud and Clear
Near colony

A selection of calls made by Rooks at a rookery. The birds' activity was relaxed and they were oblivious to my presence below them. In my experience, Rooks are normally intolerant of people near a breeding site and if disturbed will immediately move away or circle overhead, calling loudly and profusely. The rookery where the recording was made is beside a public path and, so long as walkers do not leave the path, the Rooks ignore passers-by. The range (in pitch) and diversity of vocabulary is fascinating. Much more so than Hooded and Carrion Crows, Rooks are known to have versatile voices. In Witherby's 'The Handbook of British Birds' (1940) the range in pitch of Rook's calls is stated to embrace a vocal range that is both 'somewhat lower to much higher' than Carrion and Hooded Crow.  Although the bird's notes cover many activities (such as intimate calls between pairs, feeding calls and sotto voce 'song'), the selection of sounds on the clip all relate to fairly harmonious life at a breeding colony. Nonetheless, it is possible to distinguish distinct types of notes.  One example is a fast and sharp gull-like call (also reminiscent of Osprey) after 0:16 (note that the 'gull cry' comes closer to the seventeenth second) with five further utterances coming in the few seconds after 0:20. Another distinct 'double-note' (with almost a croaking frog quality) can be heard at 0:33, 0:36, 0:46 and 0:51. Note that the overall recording has been edited from a total of about 15 minutes, within which the 'gull cry' and, separately, the 'frog croak' were concentrated. Rook's standard caw can, at times, be heard to vary slightly. At 0:02 and 0:03 the caw is closer to two syllables [ka-aah] than the more monosyllabic caws audible at, for example, 0:08. A Wren sings occasionally in the background, such as 0:03 and 0:12 and a Coal Tit sings at 0:30, 0:36 and 0:43.

XC194042-Rook juv to 23 s, then ad. 2014-07-14 1521hrs.mp3
recordings.rmk: Two Rooks in the vicinity of a garden feeder. The fully grown juvenile preferred to let the adult (presumably its parent) extricate seed and feed it. Maybe the young bird was less able to manage? The calls are a combination of the young bird's caw versus the adult. The youngster calls through the early part of the recording; the parent commences just after 0:23 and continues to the end. Apart from the adult's deeper voice, the caw's construction is similar. The sound starts abruptly, peaks, then fades. The effect is to make the overall composition neat and compact. Potentially, this might amount to a subtle distinction from the sound of Hooded Crow XC194048. In Hooded Crow and presumably Carrion Crow, there is more of a drawl throughout the utterance. Put another way, Hooded Crow produces a more slouched sound. Perhaps there is some merit in checking the discernibility of the syllables that make up the caw. In Rook, the caw amounts to an acoustic blur (because the syllables seem to merge into a wall of sound). However, in Hooded Crow, the syllables are fractionally slower. As a result, the delivery comes across as 'grinding'. Hence, Rook's squawk is smooth whereas Hooded Crow's is a touch - for want for a better word - corrugated.

recordings.rmk: wildtronics

Suspected ID.  I recorded the voice while taking a video of
tundra swans, and I didn't see the bird directly.
After taking the video, I noticed a flock of rooks (of about 100 birds).
Photographs of these birds indicated that the flock consisted of only rooks.
In addition to above circumstances, the voice almost completely lacks higher 
harmonics, while my other recordings of carrion crows (Corvus corone)
have significant power in higher frequencies.  I thereby identified
this voice as that of rook(s).
Some wind noise (not processed).
Editing (noise removal) with Audacity.
Near colony

recordings.rmk:
Recording started at mid point in time span of bird's call and ends when bird stopped calling. A noisy, fast flowing beck and an old mill race are adjacent to the location. Noise reduction software has been used to reduce this extraneous sound without distorting bird calls. Recording was done soon after sunrise on a warm, dry, cloudy day with no wind.
The call, which sounds like notes played on a recorder, usually appears to come from a small group of tall, mature alder trees which is also the site of a rookery. The trees are in the centre of a small hamlet of 20 -  30 homes surrounded by fields used for grazing livestock and for crops of winter barley. The beck is lined by mixed species of trees and there are other small areas of woodland in the locality. 
I have never seen the bird but first heard this call over several weeks in the Summer of 2013. I noticed it again in June 2014. It can be heard anytime from just before sunrise until just after sunset and continues at variable intervals for several minutes each time. Occasionally the source location changes to trees lining the beck 50 - 60 metres downstream. If I get near the source location the calls come to an abrupt halt. The only birds I have seen in these trees are rooks, jackdaws, wood pigeon and collared dove along with smaller birds including mistle thrush, blackbird, chiffchaff, chaffinch, tits and sparrows. I have sought advice from UK websites which have suggested that it is a corvid of some sort.
Bird seen and photographed making this call on 28 January 2015 - confirmed Rook (Corvus frugilegus).
